awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  3D Markerless Motion Capture Technology For Gait Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project benefitd the 70 million people struggling with gait disorders in the US. Gait analysis monitors how individuals walk to predict or prevent injuries and track rehabilitation progress. Due to the potentially high equipment costs, space requirements, and required technical expertise to collect and interpret results, detailed gait analyses are limited to a few centers and mainly used for surgical decision-making.  This project uses Artificial Intelligence (AI) for gait analysis at roughly 70% less than typical costs, as well as offering reduced set-up time and improved workflow efficiency.

The proposed project will address the existing technological and commercial barriers that make gait analysis an exclusive clinical tool restricted to only 300 gait labs across the country.  This project will develop a cost-effective markerless motion 3D-tracking system. Technical activities include: (1) increase the motion database to a diverse population, including children and patients with mobility impairments; (2) improve the computer vision algorithms to account for multiple individuals within the camera system’s field of view; (3) integrate EMG and Force Plates; (4) implement skeletal geometry estimation from computed tomography; (5) develop a self-calibration system that can operate with HD low cost cameras; and (5) improve accuracy and usability substantially to reduce the expertise required for computational gait analysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Overview:

 

This project focused on developing EvoVision, a groundbreaking 3D markerless motion capture technology designed to revolutionize gait analysis. Traditional motion capture systems rely on physical markers attached to the body, which can be cumbersome, expensive, and less accurate in natural settings. EvoVision eliminates the need for these markers by utilizing advanced computer vision algorithms and high-definition cameras, providing an unobtrusive, cost-effective, and highly accurate alternative for analyzing human movement. This technology is particularly of interest to children’s hospitals to facilitate pre-operative gait analysis for children with cerebral palsy. 

 

Intellectual Merit:

 

The EvoVision system represents a significant advancement in the field of motion capture and gait analysis. By leveraging cutting-edge technology, we have developed a system that not only improves the accuracy of motion capture but also enhances the user experience through a cloud-based architecture that allows for reduced upfront cost for users and scalable data processing. The system's ability to capture high-definition video and process large datasets in real-time marks a substantial improvement over existing solutions. This advancement is critical for research, clinical diagnostics, and sports performance, where precise and reliable motion data is essential.

 

Broader Impacts:

 

The broader impacts of EvoVision extend across multiple domains, including healthcare, sports medicine, and research. In healthcare, EvoVision provides clinicians with a powerful tool to assess and monitor patients with gait abnormalities, leading to more accurate diagnoses and personalized treatment plans. The system's ability to operate in natural environments without the need for markers opens up new possibilities for portable motion capture studies, making advanced gait analysis accessible to a broader population.

 

In sports medicine, EvoVision offers coaches and athletes a sophisticated means of analyzing performance, helping to optimize training regimens and prevent injuries. Additionally, the system's scalability and cost-effectiveness make it an attractive option for smaller clinics and research institutions that previously could not afford high-end motion capture technology.

 

Outcomes:

 

During the project period, we achieved several key milestones that have positioned EvoVision for successful commercialization. These include:

 

Development of the EvoVision System: We progressed from a preliminary prototype to a minimally viable product (MVP), with successful installation and operation at the Motion Computational Analysis Laboratory, Shirley Ryan AbilityLab, the leading rehabilitation hospital in the United States. The system's architecture was finalized, and significant software enhancements were made, enabling operation and cloud-based data processing.

 

Market Engagement and Partnerships: We engaged with potential partners and customers in healthcare and sports medicine, generating substantial interest. Collaborations with institutions such as UCSF, John Hopkins University, and partnerships with technology companies were initiated. These partnerships are crucial for validating the system's performance and ensuring its broader adoption.

 

Funding and Commercialization Efforts: We raised sufficient funds to continue to support ongoing development and commercialization efforts. The company is preparing for institutional fundraising to further accelerate market entry and product life cycle advancements. A soft launch of EvoVision has two offsite installations where we are learning from our early adopters to improve the EvoVision system. 


 

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2024
Modified by: Andrew Ekelem
